metadata.case_name: Dafedar Niranjan Singh & Anr. v. Deputy Custodian-General of Evacuee Property

facts.text: Dafedar Niranjan Singh, the first appellant, owned houses Nos. 915 and 916 in Patiala.
During the latter part of 1948, the Custodian of Evacuee Property, Patiala, took possession of the houses under Ordinance IX of 2004 on the ground that they were evacuee properties.
On January 27, 1949, Dafedar Niranjan Singh filed a claim petition before the Custodian alleging the properties belonged to him by inheritance.
Custodian by order dated June 6, 1949, allowed the claim and released the properties.
Order communicated to Assistant Custodian on June 7, 1949, and properties released pursuant thereto.
On June 9, 1955, first appellant sold a part of the properties to Major Bhagwant Singh, second appellant, for Rs. 6,000.
On June 21, 1949, Ordinance IX of 2004 repealed by Ordinance XIII of 2006.
Ordinance XIII of 2006 repealed by Ordinance XVII of 2006.
On October 18, 1949, Ordinance XVII of 2006 repealed by Central Ordinance XXVII of 1949, creating office of Custodian-General.
Central Ordinance XXVII of 1949 replaced by Administration of Evacuee Property Act No. XXXI of 1950, effective April 17, 1950.
On December 24, 1955, Litigation Inspector filed application for review of June 6, 1949 order before Custodian, Patiala.
During pendency of review, powers of review/revision under s.26 taken away by Amendment Act XCI of 1956.
On April 2, 1957, Additional Custodian submitted case to Custodian-General for suo motu action under s.27.
On May 24, 1957, Deputy Custodian-General issued notice to appellants to show cause why June 6, 1949 order be not revised.
On February 1, 1958, Deputy Custodian-General set aside June 6, 1949 order and remanded for enquiry.
Appeal by special leave against February 1, 1958 order.

legal_issues.text: Whether deeming provisions of repealing Ordinances and Acts culminating in s.58(3) of the Act apply only to administrative powers and not judicial orders passed by Custodian under Ordinance IX of 2004.
Whether chain of deeming fiction was broken when Ordinance XIII of 2006 was issued, preventing the June 6, 1949 order from being deemed under the Act.
Whether s.58(3) of the Act saves previous operation of Ordinance XXVII of 1949, preventing revision of final orders thereunder.
Whether Custodian under Ordinance IX of 2004 had jurisdiction to allow the claim, rendering the order void ab initio.

petitioner_arguments.text: Deeming provisions apply only to things done or action taken by Custodian in exercise of administrative powers and not to orders in exercise of judicial powers.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.58(3) of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950

petitioner_arguments.text: Order under Ordinance IX of 2004 cannot be deemed under the Act as chain of fiction broken by Ordinance XIII of 2006.
s.58(3) expressly saves previous operation of Ordinance XXVII of 1949, so final orders thereunder cannot be revised under s.27 of the Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.58(3) and s.28 of Ordinance XXVII of 1949; s.27 of Act

respondent_arguments.text: Custodian under Ordinance IX of 2004 had no jurisdiction to allow the claim, so order void and revisable under s.27 of Act at any time.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to s.6 of Ordinance IX of 2004; s.27 of Act

court_reasoning.text: First argument rejected as deeming provisions apply to judicial orders per Indira Sohan Lal v. Custodian.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provision applies to judicial as well as administrative acts.

court_reasoning.text: Second contention accepted: Chain broken under Ordinance XIII of 2006 as s.10(7) deems only Claims Officer orders, not Custodian's, and only for appeal/revision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order of Custodian under IX not deemed under XIII.

court_reasoning.text: Third contention accepted: s.58(3) saves previous operation; finality under Ordinance XXVII preserved, no retrospective effect disturbing final orders.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Repeal does not affect finality acquired under prior law.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent's jurisdiction argument not considered as raised first time in Supreme Court and irrelevant as concerns power to revise final orders.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.27 limited by s.58(3); no power over final prior orders.

holdings.text: Deeming provisions under s.58(3) apply to judicial orders.
Chain of deeming fiction broken at Ordinance XIII of 2006; June 6, 1949 Custodian order not deemed under Act.
s.58(3) preserves finality of orders final under prior Ordinance XXVII; not revisable under s.27 of Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indira Sohan Lal v. Custodian of Evacuee Property, Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Deeming provisions apply to judicial orders, not just administrative.

precedents_cited.case_name: Delhi Cloth and General Mills v. Income-tax Commissioner, Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Provisions touching existing final rights not retrospective absent clear intent.

precedents_cited.case_name: Colonial Sugar Refining Co. Ltd. v. Irving
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle on retrospective effect of statutes touching existing rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Janki Prasad v. The Custodian, Evacuee Property, Jullundur
precedents_cited.relevance: Incorrectly applied s.58(3) to allow review of prior order.

statutes_cited.name: Patiala Evacuees (Administration of Property) Ordinance No. IX of 2004
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowered Custodian to take possession, handle claims; decisions final.

statutes_cited.name: Patiala and East Punjab States Union Evacuees (Administration of Property) Ordinance No. XIII of 2006
statutes_cited.relevance: Claims procedure; deeming only for Claims Officer orders under prior Ordinance.

statutes_cited.name: Patiala and East Punjab States Union Evacuees (Administration of Property) Ordinance No. XVII of 2006
statutes_cited.relevance: Savings clause deeming prior actions; preserved pending claims under prior law.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Created Custodian-General; limited revision; finality of orders; savings on repeal.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 (No. XXXI of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Broadened Custodian-General revision powers; savings preserving prior finality.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property (Amendment) Act, 1956 (No. XCI of 1956)
statutes_cited.relevance: Removed review/revision powers of Custodian/Additional Custodian.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of Deputy Custodian-General dated February 1, 1958 set aside; order of Custodian dated June 6, 1949 restored.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of 1949 Custodian order releasing properties.

key_quotes.text: The chain of fiction was broken when Ordinance No. XIII of 2006 was issued.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on why order not deemed under Act.

key_quotes.text: The repeal by this Act... shall not affect the previous operation of that Ordinance... anything done... shall be deemed to have been done... subject thereto.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In the result, the order of the Custodian-General is set aside and that of the Custodian dated June 6, 1949, is restored.
key_quotes.speaker: court
